stem: The nurse is preparing to administer a bolus enteral feeding via a gastrostomy tube. Place the steps in the correct order.

options.text: Administer the prescribed feeding by gravity using a syringe.
Elevate the head of the bed to at least 30-45 degrees.
Flush the tube with an additional 30 mL of water after the feeding.
Flush the tube with 30 mL of water.
Verify tube placement and check for gastric residual volume.

rationale.correct: Safe enteral feeding prevents aspiration and tube clogging. (1) Head of bed elevation is the most effective way to prevent aspiration. (2) Checking residual prevents over-distention and vomiting (Hold if >250-500 mL depending on unit policy). (3) Pre-flush ensures patency. (4) Slow gravity flow is safer than rapid pushing. (5) Post-flush prevents residue from clogging the tube.
rationale.incorrect: Lying the client flat immediately after a feeding is a major aspiration risk.
clinicalPearls: Always return the gastric residual to the stomach to prevent electrolyte and fluid imbalances, unless the volume is excessive per protocol.

questionTrap.howToOvercome: Remember 'Gravity' is better than 'Plunger'. Never force a feeding into a patient with a syringe plunger; let it flow naturally by raising/lowering the syringe.

reviewUnits.heading: Enteral Nutrition Management
reviewUnits.body: Nurses monitor for 'Dumping Syndrome' (tachycardia, diarrhea, diaphoresis) and maintain skin integrity around the tube site.
